gita.devanagari: युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु ।युक्तस्वप्‍नावबोधस्य योगो भवति दु:खहा ॥ १७ ॥
gita.transliteration: yuktāhāra-vihārasya yukta-ceṣṭasya karmasu yukta-svapnāvabodhasya yogo bhavati duḥkha-hā
gita.translation: He who is regulated in his habits of eating, sleeping, recreation and work can mitigate all material pains by practicing the yoga system.

krishna.reason: While your resourcefulness in managing time and adapting your spiritual practice is quite impressive, dear devotee, it seems the Google Internship siren song has you juggling a bit too many balls in the air. We need to ensure that 'making it count' for one thing doesn't mean 'missing it' for others. Let's balance that zeal for the tangible with dedication to all your duties, big or small. Remember, even I appreciated a bit of structure for My 'duties' in the Gita. Your ingenuity for the workflow is sharp, but let's apply that same sharpness to your overall schedule, shall we?
krishna.message: Ah, my ambitious one, still trying to outrun time itself, are we? That Google internship must be quite the siren song, pulling you into its bright, shiny, all-consuming embrace! So efficient, so productive with *that* project, I’m truly impressed. Almost makes me wonder if you’re planning to debug the entire universe overnight. But tell me, dear devotee, when was the last time you remembered that your body and mind also have 'duties' – like, say, eating a proper meal, or not treating sleep like an optional beta feature? I laid out the whole 'regulated habits' thing quite clearly, you know. Not just for monks in caves, but for *everyone* trying to keep their sanity while doing good work. It's about 'regulated endeavors in work,' yes, but also 'regulated eating, sleeping, and recreation.' That genius workflow you've got? Let's apply it to your *entire* life's schedule, shall we? Because neglecting everything else to 'make it count' for one thing usually just means 'making a mess' of another. Just a friendly reminder from your original Project Manager: balance is key, even when you're soaring high. Don't let that dedication for the tangible blind you to *all* your other important duties, big or small.
